snippet.textDisplay: ”It” wont be fixed as long as it runs on your P2P-network, and has no region lock. Back when D1 had a million people playing ToO over the weekend, me and my friends would still match a team that was not from Europe like us at least once per passage, and it was unplayable every single time. Fix that, make the loot desirable and plentiful, and make sure its available to all skill levels and you might have a successfull mode, otherwise it will die.
snippet.textOriginal: ”It” wont be fixed as long as it runs on your P2P-network, and has no region lock. Back when D1 had a million people playing ToO over the weekend, me and my friends would still match a team that was not from Europe like us at least once per passage, and it was unplayable every single time. Fix that, make the loot desirable and plentiful, and make sure its available to all skill levels and you might have a successfull mode, otherwise it will die.

snippet.textDisplay: People are freaking out over “Light Level enabled”. BRUH it’s going to be like Iron Banner in D2, it’ll make you a LITTLE bit easier or harder to kill. Remember a couple of seasons back when there was the Iron Burden thing? That forced you to get good by lowering your Light (power) level down by 100, and it made Iron Banner more interesting by adding more of a challenge. Trials of Osiris is an ENDGAME activity, and since I’ve never gone flawless in destiny EVER I’m just happy to have a chance at that again.
snippet.textOriginal: People are freaking out over “Light Level enabled”. BRUH it’s going to be like Iron Banner in D2, it’ll make you a LITTLE bit easier or harder to kill. Remember a couple of seasons back when there was the Iron Burden thing? That forced you to get good by lowering your Light (power) level down by 100, and it made Iron Banner more interesting by adding more of a challenge. Trials of Osiris is an ENDGAME activity, and since I’ve never gone flawless in destiny EVER I’m just happy to have a chance at that again.

snippet.textDisplay: Don’t have the artifact power enabled just have gear power. The power from the artifact will give the pvp oriented players a disadvantage. And if you want to re-engage the pvp community with trials don’t have artifact power in trials. If people aren’t playing iron banner because of artifact power why would you add it to trials. Isn’t trials supposed to be the saving grace of the pvp community. Please just make sure you’re making the right decision.
snippet.textOriginal: Don’t have the artifact power enabled just have gear power. The power from the artifact will give the pvp oriented players a disadvantage. And if you want to re-engage the pvp community with trials don’t have artifact power in trials. If people aren’t playing iron banner because of artifact power why would you add it to trials. snippet.textDisplay:
When the team say "when I heard trials are coming back", you know a voice on high decided it....
Destiny has gone downhill since first release.
Desperation is taking over trying to hold on to dwindling player numbers!
For first timers the game delivers but then soon falls off.
I'm the only one left of my clan still playing.
Just mindlessly destroying ads no longer cuts it.
Obscure prolonged grinding quests don't have the mystery.
I got my Bad Juju BACK, fully mastered!
Gaining it back fell a bit flat after all the effort.
I loved the game at first, it ticked all the boxes as to why I invested in it, especially when they said there was a ten year olan.
Now it's a disappointment!
I was promised improvements in each new release, it seems they take away as much as they hype in their gives.
I might try the next season but it seems pretty doubtful.

I might try the next season but it seems pretty doubtful.

snippet.textDisplay:
The 19th European Society for Organ Transplantation (ESOT) Congress was held in Copenhagen, Denmark, from September 15 to 18, 2019. The Chinese Communist Party's (CCP) organ harvesting from living prisoners of conscience again received wide attention.

ESOT is the umbrella organization under which transplant activities are structured and streamlined in Europe and worldwide. Held every two years, the ESOT Congress attracts organ transplant leaders and experts from all over the world. More than 3,500 leading professionals in the field of organ transplants attended this year's ESOT Congress in Copenhagen on-site, and more than 1,500 participated online.

Exhibitions from the organ transplant field were held at the congress venue for the entire duration of the event. China Organ Harvest Research Center (COHRC), a non-profit organization that conducts and presents authoritative research on organ transplant abuse in China, including the killing of prisoners of conscience for their organs, participated in the exhibition.

Organ Transplant Abuse in China Receives Wide Attention
A COHRC research report on China's organ transplant abuse, and its on-demand transplants while lacking organ donors was selected to be part of the digital exhibition. The research findings stated China's astonishing development of its organ transplant industry, extremely short waiting periods, large numbers of organ transplant hospitals and surgeries, its lack of voluntary donations, and in sharp contrast its large-scale of on-demand surgeries.

The report was available for browsing on the digital screens as well as the app of the Congress, which also lets users interact with the authors of the report.

Two presentations on this topic, Abuse of Brain Death Definition in Organ Procurement in China by Huige Li of the Johannes Gutenberg-Universität Mainz Medical Center, and COHRC's Organ Transplant Abuse in China (2): Unethical Procurement Continues Despite Claims of Reform, were selected in the form of the Elevator Pitch [short description] summary on September 17.
snippet.textOriginal:
The 19th European Society for Organ Transplantation (ESOT) Congress was held in Copenhagen, Denmark, from September 15 to 18, 2019. The Chinese Communist Party's (CCP) organ harvesting from living prisoners of conscience again received wide attention. 

ESOT is the umbrella organization under which transplant activities are structured and streamlined in Europe and worldwide. Held every two years, the ESOT Congress attracts organ transplant leaders and experts from all over the world. More than 3,500 leading professionals in the field of organ transplants attended this year's ESOT Congress in Copenhagen on-site, and more than 1,500 participated online.

Exhibitions from the organ transplant field were held at the congress venue for the entire duration of the event. China Organ Harvest Research Center (COHRC), a non-profit organization that conducts and presents authoritative research on organ transplant abuse in China, including the killing of prisoners of conscience for their organs, participated in the exhibition.

Organ Transplant Abuse in China Receives Wide Attention
A COHRC research report on China's organ transplant abuse, and its on-demand transplants while lacking organ donors was selected to be part of the digital exhibition. The research findings stated China's astonishing development of its organ transplant industry, extremely short waiting periods, large numbers of organ transplant hospitals and surgeries, its lack of voluntary donations, and in sharp contrast its large-scale of on-demand surgeries.

The report was available for browsing on the digital screens as well as the app of the Congress, which also lets users interact with the authors of the report.

Two presentations on this topic, Abuse of Brain Death Definition in Organ Procurement in China by Huige Li of the Johannes Gutenberg-Universität Mainz Medical Center, and COHRC's Organ Transplant Abuse in China (2): Unethical Procurement Continues Despite Claims of Reform, were selected in the form of the Elevator Pitch [short description] summary on September 17.

snippet.textDisplay:
For those of you who don’t know, or haven’t seen the directors cut. Luke Smith is a complete idiot. His mentality on the “just make them better” when it comes to weapons is outright dumb. If you’re going to release a pinnacle activity, make the rewards worth it. Make them good and don’t make the random drops be as good if not better. That’s how the VoG weapons were originally, speaking of which since he brought it up so much in his little speech, the VoG weapons were the best and kept seeing action because they were good, hard to get and worth the effort. A weapon that can be constantly rolled for (because random perk selection is such a great idea after all...) that can have similar or better perk rolls make them more sought after more than something you have to work for, all this does is encourage laziness and the time lost bounties are proof of this. I don’t want to spend hours of my time to get a group together to finish a raid to get something I could spend the same amount of time throwing materials at the gunsmith. Its because of this issue(mostly the random rolls on every weapon) that make it not worth it to after the raid weapons or even the IB or Gambit weapons. Especially when 99% of players are going to take the easy route to get something, which is the path of least resistance.
And as far as his comment on “the blue scrapping ritual after every crucible match” this wouldn’t be a problem if they implemented the same system they did in D1 where all greens were automatically scrapped. Greens never drop anymore and as far as blues are concerned they should automatically be scrapped unless the player isn’t at the soft level cap of 960(at time of writing). The main issue I’ve come to notice is that purples are handed out way too frequently, for every 10 blues is a purple. Back in the D1 you rarely saw purples drop in the wild and the only way you saw them regularly was if you were cracking faction packages.
And lastly his ideas on removing the bright engrams from the store isn’t due to player feedback, it has more to do with the fact that bright engrams are loot boxes and are illegal in most places. This still doesn’t solve the issue of them not putting desirable items into the playable content. I don’t care if it’s cosmetic, the point is, not everything should be paid for. It makes actually playing the game less fun and more of a fashion simulator fueled by surface level grinding in the form of bounties.
There is so much to in D2 but none of it is being done because there is no actual incentive to do it. Raid weapons have random rolls and the weapons aren’t much better than their similar class counterparts. Why should I go out of my way to farm a god roll Threat level when I can get a god roll Perfect Paradox and spend way less time doing it? That and as I stated before, weapons having static rolls(good ones at that) are what made the original weapons from D1 so good.
So two things can be done about the weapons; 1) re-re-introduce static rolls and stop being bullied by your community all the time over this “because grinding rolls is “fun(shut up, no it’s not)”” and 2) reduce the legendary weapon drop rates or reduce the sources you can get them from to make them feel like actual rewards.
Now on to his remarks on content, the original game is so small(compared to D2) they could release all of it as an annual pass(relevant content free for all previous purchasers, if you bought it all once you get it all again free) incorporate that into the new light campaign and make the narrative cohesive, then introduce the D2 campaign and its content in the order of original release. And speaking of campaign, this goes into his “core content” which for as long as the game has been around and since doing bounties became more prevalent than doing actual missions. Do away with as many sources as possible. Doing bounties isn’t fun, and if you find it fun, you clearly aren’t playing any of the actual content. Running through every patrol zone everyday doing every bounty everyone has is a quick way to make people bored because there is no challenge. Nightfalls fall into this as well. Doing the ordeal over and over again expecting a different reward is just insanity defined.
I’m going to close out on crucible, with statements made yesterday on the separation of sandboxes, if this is something they’ve been capable of achieving then why hasn’t it ever been done up until now? The crucible is broken and apparently the only way to fix it is to separate its core from its comp? Why not separate it from pve as well? Everything in pve is fine except the stupidly powerful stomp mechanic, it either flings you a million miles away or it one hit kills you. So if a weapon becomes a problem on the crucible side why not completely isolate it and fix it there? I’ll tell you why, they’re lazy. They’ve been pulling this crap for years and are only doing something about it now to try and salvage what’s left of this horses corpse since it’s been savagely beaten to a pulp due to their inability to create new content without always reviving old content. Even though that’s what I’ve said would work, but at this point there is so much stuff from D1 in it anyway what difference would it make? None.

This has been my TedTalk/rant thank you for coming.

If you’re going to release a pinnacle activity, make the rewards worth it. Make them good and don’t make the random drops be as good if not better. That’s how the VoG weapons were originally, speaking of which since he brought it up so much in his little speech, the VoG weapons were the best and kept seeing action because they were good, hard to get and worth the effort. A weapon that can be constantly rolled for (because random perk selection is such a great idea after all...) that can have similar or better perk rolls make them more sought after more than something you have to work for, all this does is encourage laziness and the time lost bounties are proof of this. Its because of this issue(mostly the random rolls on every weapon) that make it not worth it to after the raid weapons or even the IB or Gambit weapons. Do away with as many sources as possible. Doing bounties isn’t fun, and if you find it fun, you clearly aren’t playing any of the actual content. Running through every patrol zone everyday doing every bounty everyone has is a quick way to make people bored because there is no challenge. Nightfalls fall into this as well. Doing the ordeal over and over again expecting a different reward is just insanity defined.
I’m going to close out on crucible, with statements made yesterday on the separation of sandboxes, if this is something they’ve been capable of achieving then why hasn’t it ever been done up until now? The crucible is broken and apparently the only way to fix it is to separate its core from its comp? Why not separate it from pve as well? Everything in pve is fine except the stupidly powerful stomp mechanic, it either flings you a million miles away or it one hit kills you. So if a weapon becomes a problem on the crucible side why not completely isolate it and fix it there? I’ll tell you why, they’re lazy. They’ve been pulling this crap for years and are only doing something about it now to try and salvage what’s left of this horses corpse since it’s been savagely beaten to a pulp due to their inability to create new content without always reviving old content. Even though that’s what I’ve said would work, but at this point there is so much stuff from D1 in it anyway what difference would it make? None.

This has been my TedTalk/rant thank you for coming.

snippet.textDisplay:
Devs on the video: " It SI a legitimately DIFFICULT thing to be good at"
Video: someone one-shotting ppl with one-button-skill-hit-the-toe-kill-the-foe.
Thanks but no thanks.
Not a fan of your PVP. No balance whatsoever - either you know meta`s and use it, or you`r just trying to do that one damn quest that forces you to do pvp with some sort of non-meta-weapon so you`r screwed, but you do it anyway because there`s no other way to get rid of that quest from your inventory\questbook.
I understand that developing those game modes takes a lot of time and effort - but that doesn't means everyone will enjoy it anyways.
Especially if you force people to do them.

snippet.textDisplay:
It's hilarious how little they are able to create for such a huge studio of over 600 people. They amount of content they pushed out for Shadowkeep, the huge "expansion", is laughable. The amount they push out every new season is laughable as well.

Path of Exile just announced their next season, look it up. It's on absolutely another level despite being completely free to play game with no paid seasons or expansion and having a quarter of developers Bungie has.

I'm gonna go out on a limb and say it: Bungie is a ridiculously LAZY, SELF-CENTERED and GREEDY company.
snippet.textOriginal:
It's hilarious how little they are able to create for such a huge studio of over 600 people. They amount of content they pushed out for Shadowkeep, the huge "expansion", is laughable. The amount they push out every new season is laughable as well.

Path of Exile just announced their next season, look it up. It's on absolutely another level despite being completely free to play game with no paid seasons or expansion and having a quarter of developers Bungie has.

I'm gonna go out on a limb and say it: Bungie is a ridiculously LAZY, SELF-CENTERED and GREEDY company.
